instruction:
You should take the time to read the situation and problem carefully and give the best advice you can.

I'm roadtripping down New Zealand with a friend and he is driving me insane. He hasn't enjoyed all the tours we've been on and doesn't want to chat about ANYTHING. We're a week into our trip and this is the quietest I've ever been when hanging out with another person as he rebuffs all my attempts at conversation. He wears his airpods in the car and around the accommodation - not that I've kept trying to talk to him. Honestly, he is bringing some seriously bad vibes to everything and it's ruining my trip.
We don't have anything booked in yet for the South Island, so I'm planning to ditch him in Wellington at the ferry. Probably book my own car in Picton and just relax alone for the rest of the trip. (Just thinking about it is such sharp relief that it makes me feel emotional. I'll pay whatever price I have to just to get away from him.)
Obviously telling him he is ruining my trip with his negative energy isn't the best way to approach this.
Any advice for the best approach so we can split amicably? Or at least not have an argument that ends with very hurt feelings?
output:
You should talk to your friend about your concerns and try to resolve the issue before you go your separate ways. It's important to communicate in a calm and respectful manner to avoid any hurt feelings.

First, try to understand why your friend may be feeling uncomfortable or uninterested in the tours or conversations you are suggesting. It's possible that they may have different interests or preferences than you, or they may be feeling tired or stressed from the road trip.

Once you have a better understanding of your friend's perspective, you can approach the conversation with a solution-focused mindset. Instead of accusing them of ruining your trip, you can express your feelings and concerns in a non-judgmental way. For example, you could say something like, "I'm feeling really excited about seeing the sights and experiencing the culture in the South Island, but I'm also a bit worried that we may not have as much fun if we're not enjoying the tours together. I'm wondering if you have any ideas for how we could make the most of our time there, even if we have different interests?"

By approaching the situation in this way, you can open up a dialogue and work together to find a solution that works for both of you. This may involve finding activities or sights that both of you are interested in, or even just giving each other some space and time to do your own thing.

Ultimately, the key to a successful and amicable split is to communicate openly and respectfully, and to be willing to compromise and find a solution that works for both parties.

instruction:
You are given a description that provides a set of facts or a scenario. It is up to you to craft a story from these facts and scenarios. The missing pieces must be filled in with imaginative but logical information.

Ten European football teams – the Netherlands, England, Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland and Wales – will participate in a season-long “OneLove” campaign promoting inclusion and opposing discrimination.
output:
Once upon a time, in a world where football was the most beloved sport, the European Football Federation decided to launch a campaign to promote inclusion and stand against discrimination. Ten teams from all over Europe, including the Netherlands, England, Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland, and Wales, joined forces to participate in the "OneLove" campaign.

The teams were united in their belief that everyone should be treated equally, regardless of their background or beliefs. They knew that football was a powerful tool to bring people together and create a better world.

The campaign kicked off with a grand opening ceremony, where all ten teams came together wearing special jerseys with the "OneLove" logo on them. The teams then went on to play their respective matches, with the message of inclusion and acceptance echoing in the stadiums.

As the season progressed, the teams continued to promote the "OneLove" campaign, organizing events and initiatives to raise awareness about the importance of inclusivity. The players and coaches also took to social media to share their support for the cause, inspiring millions of people around the world.

At the end of the season, the teams were awarded for their efforts, with the "OneLove" campaign being recognized as a shining example of how football can be used to make the world a better place. The ten teams had shown that when they stood together, they could create a powerful force for good, and their message of inclusivity and acceptance would continue to inspire generations to come.

instruction:
A job description is a document that clearly states the requirements, duties, responsibilities, and skills required to perform a specific role. You need to write a job description based on the given information. You should describe responsibilities and duties in your job description in a logical order. Remember that potential employees often get their first impression of your company from your job description. So, the job description should convey the attractiveness of your company.

Company: [Company name]
Job: Software Engineer
Job Responsibilities:
Receive and perform code reviews with other engineers.
Write unit, integration, and end-to-end tests to verify functionality using automated testing frameworks such as Pytest.
Work collaboratively with fellow software engineers to build features requested by business stakeholders.
Participate in Agile teams to develop, test, and debug complex data processing pipelines and data analysis applications using big data processing systems such as Apache Spark.
Diagnose, debug, and perform root cause analysis of issues and defects.
Skills and experience that will lead to success:
Experience with a modern software programming language. We use Python, and Pyspark extensively.
Experience with cloud systems like AWS or Azure
Experience writing SQL queries 
Strong written and verbal communication skills
Eagerness to work in a highly-collaborative environment
Some visualization experience such as Tableau or PowerBI is helpful
output:
Job Description:

Title: Software Engineer

Company: [Company name]

Job Responsibilities:

* Collaborate with other software engineers to receive and perform code reviews
* Write unit, integration, and end-to-end tests to verify functionality using automated testing frameworks such as Pytest
* Work closely with fellow engineers to build features requested by business stakeholders
* Participate in Agile teams to develop, test, and debug complex data processing pipelines and data analysis applications using big data processing systems such as Apache Spark
* Diagnose, debug, and perform root cause analysis of issues and defects
* Participate in code reviews, pair programming, and knowledge sharing sessions
* Keep up-to-date with the latest trends and best practices in software engineering
* Maintain and enhance existing codebase and contribute to the development of new features
* Write clean, maintainable, and well-documented code

Skills and experience:

* Proficiency in a modern software programming language, preferably Python and Pyspark
* Experience with cloud systems such as AWS or Azure
* Strong understanding of SQL queries
* Excellent written and verbal communication skills
* Experience with data visualization tools such as Tableau or PowerBI
* Strong problem-solving skills and ability to work in a highly-collaborative environment
* Ability to work independently and as part of a team
* Experience with Agile development methodologies
* Familiarity with software development best practices and principles
* Strong attention to detail and ability to write clean, well-documented code

We offer a dynamic and challenging work environment, opportunities for professional growth and development, and a competitive compensation package. If you are passionate about software engineering, enjoy working in a highly-collaborative environment, and are eager to work on cutting-edge projects, we encourage you to apply for this exciting opportunity.

Blog Topic: 7 Fall Fashion Trends Worth Taking on Your Trip
Section Title: Trusty Jeans
Main point of the section: jeans can be worn all year and look good with everything .
output:
Trusty Jeans: A Timeless Fashion Staple

Denim never goes out of style, and that's why jeans are a must-have in any wardrobe. They are versatile, comfortable, and can be worn all year round. This fall, jeans are a top fashion trend that is perfect for your next trip.

Jeans are a great option for travel because they are easy to pack, comfortable, and can be dressed up or down depending on the occasion. Whether you're heading to a festival or a formal dinner, a pair of dark wash jeans will always look chic. 

This fall, the trend is towards more relaxed fits, with straight-leg and wide-leg jeans being popular. These styles are easy to move around in and are perfect for exploring new cities or hiking through nature. If you prefer a more fitted look, try a high-waisted style that will flatter your figure and keep you comfortable on long flights or road trips.

When it comes to styling jeans, the possibilities are endless. Pair a pair of dark wash jeans with a cozy sweater, a leather jacket, or even a graphic tee for a casual, yet chic look. For a more formal occasion, dress up your jeans with a blazer, heels, and a statement necklace.

In conclusion, trusty jeans are a timeless fashion staple that can be worn all year round. They are perfect for travel, as they are comfortable, versatile, and easy to pack. Whether you're heading to a festival or a formal dinner, a pair of dark wash jeans will always look chic.

3. The impact of procrastination on mental health: This video can discuss the relationship between procrastination and anxiety, stress, and depression, and provide strategies for managing these effects.

4. Breaking the cycle of procrastination: This video can offer practical tips and techniques for breaking the cycle of procrastination, such as creating a schedule, setting achievable goals, and using positive self-talk.

5. The benefits of taking action: This video can discuss the benefits of taking action, such as increased confidence, productivity, and the ability to achieve goals, and provide examples of successful people who have overcome procrastination.

6. Overcoming procrastination through mindfulness: This video can explore the role of mindfulness in overcoming procrastination, such as through meditation and journaling, and provide practical exercises to try.

7. Procrastination and technology: This video can discuss the impact of technology on procrastination, such as social media and video games, and provide tips on how to limit its negative effects.

8. The role of self-discipline in overcoming procrastination: This video can explore the importance of self-discipline in overcoming procrastination and provide tips for developing this skill.

9. Procrastination and time management: This video can discuss the relationship between procrastination and time management and provide tips for using time more effectively.

10. The power of accountability: This video can discuss the importance of accountability in overcoming procrastination, such as through a support group or a coach, and provide tips for finding an accountability partner.

instruction:
Find synonyms for the given word. You need to write down how the provided synonyms differ from the original word in terms of meaning, usage, etc.

adversity
output:
1. hardship - Hardship refers to a state of difficulty or misfortune, often involving physical or financial deprivation. It is a synonym for adversity, but it implies a more specific and tangible form of suffering.
2. trouble - Trouble is a synonym for adversity that suggests a more general and often temporary state of difficulty or unpleasantness. It does not necessarily imply a prolonged period of suffering or misfortune, as adversity does.
3. misfortune - Misfortune is a synonym for adversity that refers to a specific, unlucky event or circumstance. It is often associated with negative outcomes, such as loss, injury, or failure. While adversity is broader in scope, encompassing a wide range of challenging circumstances, misfortune is more focused on specific, negative events.
4. difficulty - Difficulty is a synonym for adversity that refers to a state of being hard to accomplish or overcome. It is more general than adversity, as it can refer to any kind of challenge or obstacle, while adversity specifically refers to challenging circumstances that are difficult to overcome.

instruction:
Discuss the origins and history of the word that has been given to you.

oblique
output:
The word "oblique" comes from the Latin word "obliquus," which means "sloping" or "askew." The Latin word is derived from the adjective "obliquus," which means "not straight," or "crooked." The word "oblique" has been in use since the 14th century, and its history is closely tied to that of its Latin counterpart.

The word "oblique" has been used to describe things that are at an angle, slanting, or not perpendicular. In the context of language, it has been used to describe the slanting or diagonal writing style of some languages, such as Chinese and Japanese. In the context of geometry, it refers to a line or angle that is not perpendicular. In the context of art and design, it can be used to describe the diagonal lines or shapes in a composition.

The word "oblique" has also been used in a figurative sense, to describe someone who is unconventional or nonconformist, or to describe a situation that is not straightforward or easy to understand. This figurative use of the word reflects its historical use to describe something that is not perpendicular or straight, and instead, is at an angle or slanting.

Overall, the word "oblique" has a rich history that reflects its use to describe things that are not perpendicular or straight, and instead, are at an angle or slanting. Its use has evolved over time, and it continues to be an important word in a variety of contexts.

instruction: Write a step-by-step guide for resolving GitHub merge conflicts.
output:
1. Open the repository in GitHub and select the branch where the merge conflict occurred.
2. Identify the files that are conflicting and open them in a text editor.
3. Look for the specific lines that are causing the conflict and try to resolve them by comparing the changes made by different contributors.
4. If you are not sure how to resolve the conflict, you can try using a merge tool such as Git Merge or GitHub Desktop.
5. Once you have resolved the conflict, save the file and commit the changes.
6. Switch back to the branch where the merge occurred and push your changes to the remote repository.
7. If there are any conflicts with other files, repeat the process until all conflicts have been resolved.
8. Finally, pull the latest changes from the remote repository to ensure that everything is up to date.

instruction:
One or more jobs can be run automatically by a workflow. The workflows are defined in the repository as YAML files and will run if an event occurs in the repository, as well as manually, or on a certain schedule.
Bring an example of a workflow that demonstrate the CI/CD features of GitHub Actions.
output:
Here is an example of a GitHub Actions workflow that demonstrates CI/CD features:
```
name: Build and Deploy

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
    - name: Checkout code
      uses: actions/checkout@v2

    - name: Build the project
      run: |
        echo "Building the project..."
        npm run build

    - name: Deploy to production
      uses: appleboy/github-actions-deploy@master
      with:
        production: true
        api_key: ${{ secrets.API_KEY }}
        api_url: https://api.example.com
```
This workflow will run automatically on the `main` branch and will build and deploy the project to production when changes are pushed to the repository. The `build` job runs on an Ubuntu machine and checks out the code, builds the project using npm, and then deploys it to production using the `appleboy/github-actions-deploy` action. The `secrets.API_KEY` is used to authenticate with the production API.

Yes it's an innovative story, told via a strong script, engaging characters and intense cinematography. But is it really worthy of such high praise? Personally, I find it starts to fall apart halfway through and actually becomes quite tedious towards the end. Everything just becomes a little bit childish and contrived as the story loses touch with its base elements and the rage against the machine vibe takes over. I have huge respect for the way this film was made but, much like The Matrix, I feel like people attach way more importance to this movie than it deserves.

Although, majority of reviews find this movie entertaining and interesting, yet I would choose to be a minority that believes that this movie is extremely overrated.
Review 4: Is creating chaos, explosions and membership in a militant sect the way to get rid of material shackles ?! The visual effects are fascinating and the story is compelling until the second half. Unfortunately, it doesn't end well.

- Innovative story

- Engaging characters
- Intense cinematography
- Good theme
- Great acting
- Important messages
- Unorthodox way of storytelling

Negative points:
- Ed Norton grates on the reviewer

- Rage against the machine vibe takes over

instruction:
Answer the following question.

How do I compare strings in Java?
I've been using the == operator in my program to compare all my strings so far. However, I ran into a bug, changed one of them into .equals() instead, and it fixed the bug.
Is == bad? When should it and should it not be used? What's the difference?
output: The == operator is not bad, but it should be used with care. The == operator checks if two objects are the same object in memory. It does not check if the contents of the object are the same. For example, two different objects with the same reference will return true with the == operator. The .equals() method checks if the contents of the objects are the same. It is used to compare the contents of two objects.

instruction:
Provide a Java solution to the following problem.

Given an integer n, return true if it is a power of three. Otherwise, return false.
An integer n is a power of three, if there exists an integer x such that n == 3^x.

Example 1:
In: n = 27
Out: true
Explanation: 27 = 3^3

Example 2:
In: n = 0
Out: false
Explanation: There is no x where 3^x = 0.

Example 3:
In: n = -1
Out: false
Explanation: There is no x where 3x = (-1).
 
Constraints:
-231 <= n <= 231 - 1
Follow up: Could you solve it without loops/recursion?

instruction:
You will need to guide this person through the scenario they have described for the interview.

Finally! After a while of shooting in the dark and frantically fiddling with sample inputs on the whiteboard, you've came up with an algorithm for solving the coding question your interviewer gave you.
Whew. Such a relief to have a clear path forward. To not be flailing anymore.
Now you're cruising, getting ready to code up your solution.
When suddenly, your interviewer throws you a curve ball.
"What if we thought of the problem this way?"
You feel a tension we've all felt during the coding interview:
"Try to listen to what they're saying...but don't lose your train of thought...ugh, I can't do both!"
output:
It sounds like you are in the middle of a coding interview and your interviewer has just presented a new perspective on the problem you were working on. It can be challenging to switch gears and adapt to a new approach, but it's important to stay focused and listen carefully to what your interviewer is saying.

First, take a moment to process the new information and consider how it relates to the problem you were working on before. Ask clarifying questions if you need more information. It's important to make sure you understand the new approach and how it differs from the original problem.

Once you have a good understanding of the new approach, start fresh with the new problem and work through it step by step. Remember to keep track of your thought process and any decisions you make along the way. If you get stuck, don't be afraid to ask for help or clarification.

Remember, the goal of a coding interview is to demonstrate your problem-solving skills and your ability to adapt to new challenges. By staying focused, communicating effectively, and adapting to the new approach, you can show your interviewer that you are a strong candidate for the job.

instruction:
You are given a programming problem and its implementation. Analyze the problem and implementation and explain the algorithm and approach used to solve the problem.

Table: Person
| Column Name | Type     |
| personId          | int         |
| lastName         | varchar |
| firstName         | varchar |
personId is the primary key column for this table.
This table contains information about the ID of some persons and their first and last names.
Table: Address
| Column Name | Type     |
| addressId        | int         |
| personId          | int         |
| city                   | varchar|
| state                | varchar |
addressId is the primary key column for this table.
Each row of this table contains information about the city and state of one person with ID = PersonId.
Write an SQL query to report the first name, last name, city, and state of each person in the Person table. If the address of a personId is not present in the Address table, report null instead.
Return the result table in any order.
Implementation:
select FirstName, LastName, City, State
from Person left join Address
on Person.PersonId = Address.PersonId
;
output:
The problem is to find the first name, last name, city, and state of each person in the Person table. If the address of a personId is not present in the Address table, the result should be null.
The solution is to use a left outer join with the Address table. The left join will return all the rows from the Person table and matching rows from the Address table. If there is no match, the result will be null.
The query selects the first name, last name, city, and state columns from both the Person and Address tables. The join condition is set to match the personId column between the two tables.

instruction:
Summarize the article you have been given in a brief manner.

Mathematics and art are related in a variety of ways. Mathematics has itself been described as an art motivated by beauty. Mathematics can be discerned in arts such as music, dance, painting, architecture, sculpture, and textiles. This article focuses, however, on mathematics in the visual arts.
Mathematics and art have a long historical relationship. Artists have used mathematics since the 4th century BC when the Greek sculptor Polykleitos wrote his Canon, prescribing proportions conjectured to have been based on the ratio 1:√2 for the ideal male nude. Persistent popular claims have been made for the use of the golden ratio in ancient art and architecture, without reliable evidence. In the Italian Renaissance, Luca Pacioli wrote the influential treatise De divina proportione (1509), illustrated with woodcuts by Leonardo da Vinci, on the use of the golden ratio in art. Another Italian painter, Piero della Francesca, developed Euclid's ideas on perspective in treatises such as De Prospectiva Pingendi, and in his paintings. The engraver Albrecht Dürer made many references to mathematics in his work Melencolia I. In modern times, the graphic artist M. C. Escher made intensive use of tessellation and hyperbolic geometry, with the help of the mathematician H. S. M. Coxeter, while the De Stijl movement led by Theo van Doesburg and Piet Mondrian explicitly embraced geometrical forms. Mathematics has inspired textile arts such as quilting, knitting, cross-stitch, crochet, embroidery, weaving, Turkish and other carpet-making, as well as kilim. In Islamic art, symmetries are evident in forms as varied as Persian girih and Moroccan zellige tilework, Mughal jali pierced stone screens, and widespread muqarnas vaulting.
output: The article discusses the long-standing relationship between mathematics and the visual arts, highlighting examples of mathematical concepts and principles that have been employed by artists throughout history, up to modern times.

instruction:
Improve the article using your knowledge of the topic in order to make it more informative.

The "fair trade" movement, also known as the "trade justice" movement, promotes the use of labour, environmental and social standards for the production of commodities, particularly those exported from the Third and Second Worlds to the First World. Such ideas have also sparked a debate on whether trade itself should be codified as a human right.
output:
The fair trade movement, also known as trade justice, is a social movement that promotes the use of labor, environmental, and social standards for the production and trade of goods, particularly those exported from the developing countries to the developed countries. The movement seeks to ensure that the producers of these goods are treated fairly and ethically, and that the products are produced sustainably and with respect for the environment.

The fair trade movement has also led to a broader debate on whether trade should be recognized as a human right. This debate centers on the idea that access to safe and fair trade should be considered a fundamental right for all individuals, regardless of their country of origin or socioeconomic status. Proponents of this view argue that the lack of access to fair trade can lead to poverty, exploitation, and injustice, and that the fair trade movement can help to address these issues by promoting ethical and sustainable production practices.

The fair trade movement has gained significant traction in recent years, with more and more consumers choosing to purchase fair trade products. This has led to an increase in the number of fair trade certifications, such as Fairtrade International and Fair Trade USA, which verify that products meet certain standards of social and environmental responsibility.

In conclusion, the fair trade movement is a social movement that promotes the use of labor, environmental, and social standards for the production and trade of goods. The movement has also led to a broader debate on whether trade should be recognized as a human right. This debate centers on the idea that access to safe and fair trade should be considered a fundamental right for all individuals, regardless of their country of origin or socioeconomic status.

instruction:

Dentistry, also known as dental medicine and oral medicine, is the branch of medicine focused on the teeth, gums, and mouth. It consists of the study, diagnosis, prevention, management, and treatment of diseases, disorders, and conditions of the mouth, most commonly focused on dentition (the development and arrangement of teeth) as well as the oral mucosa. Dentistry may also encompass other aspects of the craniofacial complex including the temporomandibular joint. The practitioner is called a dentist.
Translate to French:
output: La dentisterie, également connue sous le nom de médecine dentaire et de médecine buccale, est la branche de la médecine axée sur les dents, les gencives et la bouche. Elle consiste en l'étude, la diagnostic, la prévention, la gestion et le traitement des maladies, des troubles et des conditions de la bouche, principalement axées sur la dentition (le développement et l'arrangement des dents) ainsi que sur la muqueuse buccale. La dentisterie peut également inclure d'autres aspects de l'ensemble crâniofaccial, y compris le joint temporomandibulaire. Le praticien est appelé un dentiste.

instruction:
Design a syllabus for the given course. Students should be given a list of the chapters with brief explanations of each chapter's purpose.

Programming for Everybody (Getting Started with Python)
output:
Course Title: Programming for Everybody (Getting Started with Python)

Course Description: This course is designed to introduce students with no prior programming experience to the basics of programming and the Python language. The course will cover the fundamentals of programming, including data types, control structures, functions, and object-oriented programming. Students will also learn how to write Python programs to solve real-world problems, and how to work with data using Python libraries.

Course Objectives:

- Understand the basics of programming, including data types, control structures, functions, and object-oriented programming.
- Learn how to write Python programs to solve real-world problems.
- Learn how to work with data using Python libraries.
- Understand the basics of object-oriented programming in Python.
- Gain experience in debugging and testing Python programs.
- Learn how to read and write Python documentation.

Course Outline:

Chapter 1: Introduction to Programming and Python
- Introduction to programming and the Python language
- Basic concepts of programming, such as variables, data types, and operators
- Installing Python and setting up the development environment

Chapter 2: Control Structures
- Conditional statements (if, else, elif)
- Loops (for, while)
- Nested loops

Chapter 3: Functions
- Defining and calling functions
- Passing arguments and returning values
- Variadic functions

Chapter 4: Object-Oriented Programming
- Classes and objects
- Inheritance and polymorphism
- Encapsulation and abstraction

Chapter 5: Working with Data
- Reading and writing files
- Working with strings and lists
- Dictionaries and sets
- Data visualization with Python libraries (e.g. Matplotlib, Seaborn)

Chapter 6: Debugging and Testing
- Debugging techniques
- Testing and debugging with assertions
- Debugging with the Python debugger

Chapter 7: Reading and Writing Python Documentation
- Python documentation standards
- Creating and editing documentation with Sphinx
- Writing comments and docstrings

instruction: Give students tips on how to keep their nerves under control during class presentations.
output:
1. Practice: The more you practice your presentation, the more comfortable and confident you will feel when you are actually delivering it.

2. Deep breathing: Take deep breaths and try to relax your body before you go on stage. This will help you to stay calm and focused.

3. Visualize success: Imagine yourself delivering a successful and confident presentation. This will help to boost your confidence and reduce anxiety.

4. Use positive self-talk: Replace negative thoughts with positive affirmations. For example, instead of thinking “I’m going to mess this up,” say to yourself “I’ve practiced this, and I know I can do it.”

5. Set goals: Set achievable goals for your presentation, such as delivering your speech without any major mistakes or receiving positive feedback from your audience.

6. Take breaks: If you feel yourself getting overwhelmed or anxious, take a quick break and remind yourself of your goals and why you are giving the presentation.

7. Get support: Ask a friend or family member to practice with you or to offer support on the day of your presentation.

8. Don’t compare yourself to others: Remember that everyone has their own strengths and weaknesses, and it’s okay if you don’t perform exactly like others. Just focus on your own delivery and the message you want to convey.

instruction: You can easily make your holidays more eco-friendly by following these simple steps:

4. Use energy-efficient appliances: Use energy-efficient appliances and lighting to reduce your energy consumption.

5. Reduce water usage: Take shorter showers and turn off the faucet while brushing your teeth to reduce water usage.

6. Support local businesses: Support local businesses and buy locally grown produce to reduce your carbon footprint from transportation.

7. Reduce packaging: Bring your own reusable containers and bags to reduce packaging waste.

8. Support eco-friendly activities: Participate in eco-friendly activities such as beach cleanups or hiking to reduce your impact on the environment.

9. Educate others: Educate your friends and family about the importance of eco-friendly holidays and encourage them to follow these steps as well.

10. Stay informed: Stay informed about environmental issues and take action to reduce your impact on the environment.

output:
Idea: Turning Old Electronics into a Miniature Desk Organizer

1. Gather materials: Collect old electronic devices, such as calculators, printers, and keyboards, that are no longer in use. Ensure that the materials are safe to handle and do not pose a risk of injury or harm.

3. Assess the materials: Evaluate the materials and determine which parts can be repurposed for the desk organizer. For example, calculator buttons could be used to create a unique key holder, while printer components could be used to create a paperweight.
4. Design the organizer: Sketch out a design for the desk organizer using the available materials. Consider the size and shape of the materials, as well as their functionality, to create a cohesive and aesthetically pleasing design.
5. Create the organizer: Follow the design plan to create the miniature desk organizer. Use glue, screws, or other fasteners to secure the components together.
6. Personalize the organizer: Add any additional details or embellishments to the organizer to make it unique. This could include painting the components, adding decorative elements, or incorporating other recycled materials.
7. Test and refine the organizer: Ensure that the organizer is functional and secure, and make any necessary adjustments to improve its performance.
8. Document the process: Take photos and videos of the organizer's creation, as well as any challenges or obstacles faced along the way, to share with others.
9. Submit the Instructable: Create an Instructable detailing the process of creating the miniature desk organizer, including photos and videos, and submit it to the contest.

instruction:
Provide a detailed explanation of the steps that are required in order to construct the given project.

Steam Engine Using an Empty Beer Can
output:
Constructing a steam engine using an empty beer can is a fun and educational project that can be undertaken by anyone with basic knowledge of engineering and mechanics. Here are the steps to follow to build your own steam engine using an empty beer can:

1. Gather materials: You will need the following materials to build your steam engine:

- An empty beer can
- A piece of metal rod or wire (e.g. a bicycle spoke)
- A small nail or staple
- A rubber band
- A cork or rubber stopper
- A piece of PVC pipe (1-2 inches in diameter)
- A small container (e.g. a jar)
- A metal or plastic funnel
- A small piece of wood or cardboard (for a base)
- A small amount of water

2. Prepare the beer can: Cut the top off of the beer can with the nail or staple. Remove the top, leaving a small opening.

3. Create the steam chamber: Take the PVC pipe and cut it to fit the beer can. Attach the PVC pipe to the opening of the can with the rubber band. The rubber band will act as a gasket, creating a seal to prevent the steam from escaping.

4. Create the condenser: Take the small container and drill a hole in the bottom. Attach the funnel to the top of the container. The condenser will collect the water vapor that escapes from the steam chamber and condense it back into liquid water.

5. Fill the condenser with water: Fill the condenser with water.

6. Light the fire: Light a match or any other ignition source, and place it underneath the beer can.

7. Observe: As the fire burns, it will generate steam. The steam will pass through the PVC pipe and into the condenser, where it will condense back into water. The water will then drain back into the container, completing the cycle.

8. Adjust and observe: You may need to adjust the size of the fire or the placement of the beer can to achieve the desired amount of steam and pressure. You can also experiment with different materials and shapes to improve the efficiency of your steam engine.

In conclusion, building a steam engine using an empty beer can is a fun and educational project that can be undertaken by anyone with basic knowledge of engineering and mechanics. It can also be a great way to learn about the principles of steam power and the basics of boiler design.

instruction: Develop a mental exercise that can help people manage their anxiety and explain how it works.
output:
One mental exercise that can help people manage their anxiety is the 4-7-8 breathing technique. This exercise involves taking slow, deep breaths in through the nose for a count of four, holding the breath for a count of seven, and then exhaling through the mouth for a count of eight. This technique helps to slow down the heart rate and calm the mind, thus reducing anxiety.

To perform the 4-7-8 breathing technique, sit comfortably with your back straight and your shoulders relaxed. Start by taking a deep breath in through your nose for a count of four, and then hold it for a count of seven. As you exhale, do so through your mouth for a count of eight. Repeat this process for several breaths until you feel your anxiety levels start to decrease.

The 4-7-8 breathing technique works by activating the body's parasympathetic nervous system, which is responsible for the relaxation response. By slowing down the breathing and focusing on the sensation of the breath, the body is able to release tension and anxiety. Over time, with regular practice, this technique can become a powerful tool for managing anxiety and promoting overall relaxation.

instruction: Come up with healthy and easy dinner ideas for weeknights.
output:
1. One-pot pasta with garlic and broccoli: Cook spaghetti in boiling water and add sliced garlic and steamed broccoli to the pot. Serve with grated Parmesan cheese.

2. Stir-fry with tofu and mixed vegetables: Cook diced tofu with mixed vegetables like bell peppers, carrots, and onions in a wok or skillet. Serve with rice.

3. Baked salmon with roasted vegetables: Season a salmon fillet with lemon juice, salt, and pepper and bake in the oven with mixed vegetables like asparagus, zucchini, and cherry tomatoes.

4. Slow cooker chili with beans and vegetables: Cook ground beef with diced onions, garlic, and bell peppers in a slow cooker. Add canned beans, tomato sauce, and water and cook on low heat for 6-8 hours. Serve with cornbread.

5. Grilled chicken with roasted sweet potatoes: Marinate chicken breasts in a mixture of olive oil, lemon juice, garlic, and herbs. Grill and serve with roasted sweet potatoes and green salad.

6. Spaghetti squash with tomato sauce: Cook spaghetti squash in boiling water and top with your favorite tomato sauce. Sprinkle with Parmesan cheese and basil before serving.

7. Vegetable stir-fry with quinoa: Cook quinoa and sauté mixed vegetables like bell peppers, onions, and mushrooms in a wok or skillet. Serve with a dollop of sour cream or yogurt.

All of these recipes are healthy, easy to make, and can be prepared within 30 minutes.

instruction:
Describe how to prepare the given food in your own words. Note down the ingredients you will need and the steps you will take to prepare them.

Chewy Chocolate Chip Cookies
output:
Chewy Chocolate Chip Cookies are a delicious treat that are quick and easy to prepare. Here are the ingredients and steps to make them:

Ingredients:
- 1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
- 1/2 cup granulated sugar
- 1/2 cup brown sugar
- 2 teaspoons baking powder
- 1/2 teaspoon salt
- 1/2 cup unsalted butter, softened
- 1/2 cup white sugar
- 1/2 cup dark brown sugar
- 4 large eggs
- 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
- 2 cups semisweet chocolate chips

Steps:
1. Preheat your oven to 375°F (190°C).
2. In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, and salt.
3. In a large bowl, cream together the butter and sugars until light and fluffy.
4. Beat in the eggs one at a time, then add the vanilla extract.
5. Gradually mix in the flour mixture until just combined.
6. Stir in the chocolate chips.
7. Drop the dough by rounded tablespoons onto a baking sheet lined with parchment paper.
8. Bake for 10-12 minutes, or until the edges are lightly golden.
9. Let the cookies cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes before transferring them to a wire rack to cool completely.

Enjoy your delicious homemade Chewy Chocolate Chip Cookies!

instruction: Suggest a recipe for a vegan dessert.
output:
Vegan Chocolate Mousse Recipe:

Ingredients:
- 1 can of full-fat coconut milk
- 1/4 cup of raw cacao powder
- 1/4 cup of maple syrup
- 1 tablespoon of vanilla extract
- 1 teaspoon of sea salt
- 1/2 cup of fresh raspberries

Instructions:

1. Open the can of coconut milk and scoop out the solidified coconut cream. Discard the rest.

2. In a blender, combine the coconut cream, cacao powder, maple syrup, vanilla extract, and sea salt. Blend until smooth and creamy.

3. Pour the mixture into a bowl and chill in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours.

4. Before serving, garnish with fresh raspberries.

Enjoy your delicious vegan chocolate mousse!

instruction:
Solve this equation.

x^3 - 4x^2 + 6x - 24 = 0
output:
To solve this equation, we can use the quadratic formula:

x = (-b ± √(b^2 - 4ac)) / 2a

In this case, a = 1, b = -24, and c = -24.

x = (-(-24) ± √((-24)^2 - 4(1)(-24))) / 2(1)
x = (24 ± √(576 - 96)) / 2
x = (24 ± √(480)) / 2
x = (24 ± 20) / 2
x = (44 ± 10) / 2

So, the solutions to the equation are x = 14 and x = -6.

"If x is a positive integer or a solution to x+3>4, then x>0 and x>12."
output:
The statement is true for all values of x that are positive integers or solutions to x+3>4.

Proof:

First, let's consider the case where x is a positive integer. In this case, x is greater than zero by definition. 

Next, let's consider the case where x is a solution to x+3>4. In this case, x+3 must be greater than 4, so x must be greater than 1.

Together, these two cases show that if x is a positive integer or a solution to x+3>4, then x>0 and x>12.

Therefore, the statement is true.

instruction:
Give a brief explanation of the requested part of the paper.

Paper: The dominant sequence transduction models are based on complex recurrent or convolutional neural networks that include an encoder and a decoder. The best performing models also connect the encoder and decoder through an attention mechanism. We propose a new simple network architecture, the Transformer, based solely on attention mechanisms, dispensing with recurrence and convolutions entirely. Experiments on two machine translation tasks show these models to be superior in quality while being more parallelizable and requiring significantly less time to train. Our model achieves 28.4 BLEU on the WMT 2014 English-to-German translation task, improving over the existing best results, including ensembles, by over 2 BLEU. On the WMT 2014 English-to-French translation task, our model establishes a new single-model state-of-the-art BLEU score of 41.8 after training for 3.5 days on eight GPUs, a small fraction of the training costs of the best models from the literature. We show that the Transformer generalizes well to other tasks by applying it successfully to English constituency parsing both with large and limited training data.
Explain: The dominant sequence transduction models
output: The paper is discussing the most popular and effective sequence transduction models, which involve complex neural network architectures including encoder-decoder and attention mechanisms. The authors propose a new architecture called the Transformer, which is based solely on attention mechanisms and eliminates the need for recurrent and convolutional layers. The results from the experiments show that this new model performs better in terms of quality and is more parallelizable, making it faster to train.

instruction:
Answer the question about the paper after reading it carefully.

To evaluate if the Transformer can generalize to other tasks we performed experiments on English constituency parsing. This task presents specific challenges: the output is subject to strong structural constraints and is significantly longer than the input. Furthermore, RNN sequence-to-sequence models have not been able to attain state-of-the-art results in small-data regimes.
Question: What is English constituency parsing?
output: English constituency parsing is a task for which the output is subject to strong structural constraints and is significantly longer than the input.

instruction: Recommend some helpful activities or conversation starters to use at meetups to break the ice.
output:
Sure, here are some activities and conversation starters that could be helpful for breaking the ice at a meetup:

1. Icebreaker game: Have everyone introduce themselves with a unique fact about themselves, such as their favorite hobby or a recent trip they took.
2. Group discussion: Have a facilitated group discussion on a relevant topic, such as the future of the industry or a recent development in the field.
3. Speed networking: Have a speed networking session where individuals have a short amount of time to introduce themselves and exchange contact information with others.
4. Group activity: Organize a group activity, such as a team-building exercise or a group project, to encourage interaction and collaboration.
5. Q&A session: Have a Q&A session with a guest speaker or industry expert to encourage engagement and conversation.
6. Roundtable discussion: Organize a roundtable discussion where individuals can share their thoughts and experiences on a relevant topic.
7. Group challenge: Organize a group challenge, such as a trivia game or a scavenger hunt, to encourage teamwork and friendly competition.
8. Group brainstorming: Have a group brainstorming session where individuals can share their ideas and insights on a relevant topic.
9. Group photo: Take a group photo to create a memorable moment and encourage social interaction.
10. Social media challenge: Create a social media challenge, such as a hashtag or photo challenge, to encourage engagement and interaction on social media.

instruction:
Extract the method that has been used in the research from the abstract of the paper. Give the exact sentences from the abstract that discuss the method.

We present a state-of-the-art speech recognition system developed using end-to-end deep learning. Our architecture is significantly simpler than traditional speech systems, which rely on laboriously engineered processing pipelines; these traditional systems also tend to perform poorly when used in noisy environments. In contrast, our system does not need hand-designed components to model background noise, reverberation, or speaker variation, but instead directly learns a function that is robust to such effects. We do not need a phoneme dictionary, nor even the concept of a "phoneme." Key to our approach is a well-optimized RNN training system that uses multiple GPUs, as well as a set of novel data synthesis techniques that allow us to efficiently obtain a large amount of varied data for training. Our system, called Deep Speech, outperforms previously published results on the widely studied Switchboard Hub5'00, achieving 16.0% error on the full test set. Deep Speech also handles challenging noisy environments better than widely used, state-of-the-art commercial speech systems.Collapse
output: The method used in this research is end-to-end deep learning. The authors have used an architecture that is simpler than traditional speech systems and does not need hand-designed components to model background noise, reverberation, or speaker variation. They have used a well-optimized RNN training system that uses multiple GPUs and a set of novel data synthesis techniques to obtain a large amount of varied data for training.

instruction:
Create a short, concise summary of the paper based on its abstract.

Few-shot learning (FSL) is one of the key future steps in machine learning and raises a lot of attention. In this paper, we focus on the FSL problem of dialogue understanding, which contains two closely related tasks: intent detection and slot filling. Dialogue understanding has been proven to benefit a lot from jointly learning the two sub-tasks. However, such joint learning becomes challenging in the few-shot scenarios: on the one hand, the sparsity of samples greatly magnifies the difficulty of modeling the connection between the two tasks; on the other hand, how to jointly learn multiple tasks in the few-shot setting is still less investigated. In response to this, we introduce FewJoint, the first FSL benchmark for joint dialogue understanding. FewJoint provides a new corpus with 59 different dialogue domains from real industrial API and a code platform to ease FSL experiment set-up, which are expected to advance the research of this field. Further, we find that insufficient performance of the few-shot setting often leads to noisy sharing between two sub-task and disturbs joint learning. To tackle this, we guide slot with explicit intent information and propose a novel trust gating mechanism that blocks low-confidence intent information to ensure high quality sharing. Besides, we introduce a Reptile-based meta-learning strategy to achieve better generalization in unseen few-shot domains. In the experiments, the proposed method brings significant improvements on two datasets and achieve new state-of-the-art performance.
output: The paper introduces FewJoint, a benchmark for few-shot learning in dialogue understanding, and proposes a novel method for jointly learning intent detection and slot filling in the few-shot setting.

instruction:
Someone gives you some information about where they want to go and what they enjoy seeing and doing. Describe a proper road trip for them and find the best stops and sctivities in the way.

I'm looking for a west coast road trip. My goal is to start near San Diego and travel to Los Angeles.
output:
A perfect west coast road trip from San Diego to Los Angeles would be approximately 100 miles. This road trip would take around 2 hours and 30 minutes.

The first stop would be the famous Balboa Park. This park is home to the San Diego Museum of Art, the San Diego Zoo, and the San Diego Botanic Garden. Visitors can spend the day exploring the park and the various museums and gardens it has to offer.

Next, the drive would take you through the beautiful coastal town of Encinitas. This charming beach town offers great surfing spots, and the perfect place to grab a bite to eat at one of the many beachfront restaurants.

From Encinitas, the drive continues along the coast towards Los Angeles, passing through the charming coastal town of Laguna Beach. Visitors can take a stroll along the beach, or enjoy the art galleries and shops that line the town's main street.

Upon arrival in Los Angeles, the first stop would be the iconic Hollywood Walk of Fame. Visitors can take a stroll down the famous sidewalk, and visit the nearby TCL Chinese Theatre and the Dolby Theatre.

The next stop would be the Griffith Observatory, located on the southern slope of Mount Hollywood in Los Angeles' Griffith Park. This observatory offers stunning views of the city, and is a great place to learn about astronomy and the universe.

Lastly, the drive would take you through the downtown area of Los Angeles, passing by the historic Union Station, the Civic Center, and the iconic Los Angeles City Hall.

Overall, this road trip offers a mix of natural beauty, cultural attractions, and great food and drink.

instruction: Create a template in markdown to create scope for Jira tickets. Members should use this template as a checklist to ensure they have included all the necessary information when creating a ticket.
output:
## Jira Ticket Scope Template

To ensure all necessary information is included in a Jira ticket, please follow this template as a checklist:

1. **Summary**: Provide a brief and clear description of the issue.

2. **Description**: Explain the problem in detail, including any relevant context and steps to reproduce it if applicable.

3. **Steps to Reproduce**: List the steps necessary to replicate the issue.

4. **Expected Result**: Describe the expected outcome when following the steps to reproduce.

5. **Actual Result**: Describe the actual outcome when following the steps to reproduce.

6. **Screenshots/Attachments**: Include any relevant screenshots or attachments to aid in understanding the issue.

7. **Environment**: Identify the environment (e.g., platform, operating system, browser) in which the issue occurred.

8. **User Affected**: Identify the user or users affected by the issue.

9. **Priority**: Assign a priority level to the ticket (e.g., high, medium, low).

10. **Assignee**: Assign the ticket to a team member responsible for addressing the issue.

11. **Due Date**: Establish a due date for the resolution of the ticket.

12. **Notes**: Include any additional notes or comments relevant to the issue.

By following this template, members can ensure that all necessary information is included in a Jira ticket, promoting efficient issue resolution.

The objective of this task is to improve the onboarding process for new employees. Currently, the onboarding process is manual and time-consuming. instruction:
Make a list of the pros and cons of the given decision.

Implementing a Remote Working Policy
output:
Pros:
1. Increased Flexibility: Remote working allows employees to work from any location, giving them more flexibility in their schedules and work arrangements.
2. Improved Productivity: Studies have shown that remote workers are more productive than office-based workers, as they have fewer distractions and more autonomy.
3. Reduced Costs: Remote working can significantly reduce the costs associated with maintaining an office space, such as rent, utilities, and office equipment.
4. Increased Attraction and Retention of Talent: Offering remote working options can make a company more attractive to job seekers and can improve employee retention.
5. Better Work-Life Balance: Remote working allows employees to balance their work and personal lives more effectively, which can lead to increased job satisfaction and reduced stress.

Cons:
1. Communication Challenges: Remote workers may face challenges in communicating with colleagues and managers, which can lead to misunderstandings and delays in decision-making.
2. Lack of Collaboration: Remote workers may miss out on the benefits of collaborative work, such as brainstorming and problem-solving, which can negatively impact teamwork and innovation.
3. Increased Isolation: Remote workers may experience feelings of isolation, which can negatively impact mental health and wellbeing.
4. Security and Data Protection: Remote workers may be more vulnerable to cyber-attacks and data breaches, which can put sensitive information at risk.
5. Difficulty in Managing Performance: Managing remote workers can be more challenging than managing office-based workers, as it can be difficult to monitor productivity and performance.

instruction:
Include important study notes and key points that someone should know about the given subject.

history of the USA
output:
The history of the USA is vast and complex, covering thousands of years of human habitation and migration. Here are some key points and important study notes:

1. Pre-Columbian Era: Before the arrival of European explorers, the land that is now the United States was inhabited by various indigenous peoples. The pre-Columbian era saw the rise and fall of numerous civilizations, including the Anasazi, the Mississippians, and the Iroquois.

2. European Exploration and Colonization: Christopher Columbus led the first European expedition to the Americas in 1492, sparking a wave of European colonization. The Spanish, French, Dutch, and British all established colonies along the eastern seaboard, with the British eventually gaining control of most of the land.

3. American Revolution: The British colonies in America rebelled against their mother country in the mid-18th century, leading to the American Revolution. The war was won by the colonies, and the Treaty of Paris in 1783 recognized the independence of the United States of America.

4. Constitutional Convention: In 1787, a Constitutional Convention was held to draft a new constitution for the United States. The document established the framework for a federal government with three branches: the legislative, executive, and judicial.

5. Civil War: In the mid-19th century, the United States was torn apart by the issue of slavery. The North and South clashed in the Civil War, fought from 1861 to 1865. The Union emerged victorious, and the 13th Amendment to the Constitution abolished slavery.

6. Industrial Revolution and Westward Expansion: The latter half of the 19th century saw the United States undergo rapid industrialization and westward expansion. The transcontinental railroad was completed in 1869, and the United States acquired Alaska from Russia in 1867 and Hawaii in 1898.

7. World War I and II: The United States became a major world power after its victory in World War I, and played a key role in the Allied victory in World War II. The country emerged from the war as one of the world's superpowers.

8. Cold War and the Space Race: During the Cold War, the United States and the Soviet Union engaged in a rivalry that included a space race, with the United States successfully landing astronauts on the moon in 1969.

9. Civil Rights Movement: The mid-20th century saw the United States struggle with issues of racial equality and civil rights. The movement, led by figures like Martin Luther King Jr., resulted in the passing of landmark legislation such as the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

10. Contemporary History: The United States has continued to play a major role on the global stage in the decades since the end of the Cold War. Key events include the 9/11 terrorist attacks, the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, and the election of the first African American president, Barack Obama, in 2008.

instruction: For a quick and efficient office workout, suggest a short routine.
output:
Here is a quick and efficient office workout routine that can be done in less than 10 minutes:

1. Warm up with some light stretching, such as touching your toes, stretching your arms and legs, and rotating your neck.

2. Do 30 seconds of jumping jacks to get your heart rate up and burn some calories.

3. Do 30 seconds of mountain climbers to work your core and improve your balance.

4. Do 30 seconds of push-ups to work your chest, triceps, and shoulders.

5. Do 30 seconds of lunges to work your legs and improve your balance.

6. Do 30 seconds of plank to work your abs and arms.

7. Finish with 30 seconds of high knees to get your heart rate back up and burn some more calories.

This short routine can be done multiple times throughout the day to help you stay energized and focused. Remember to listen to your body and take breaks as needed.

instruction:
Using the ingredients that are available, create a dinner recipe.

Kale + almond butter + apple cider vinegar + agave nectar + tamari
output:
Kale and Apple Cider Vinegar Dressing with Almond Butter and Agave Nectar

Ingredients:
- 1 bunch of kale
- 1/4 cup of almond butter
- 1 tablespoon of apple cider vinegar
- 1 tablespoon of agave nectar
- 2 tablespoons of tamari
- Salt and pepper to taste

Instructions:
1. Begin by washing the kale thoroughly and removing the stems.
2. In a small bowl, whisk together the almond butter, apple cider vinegar, agave nectar, and tamari.
3. Add a pinch of salt and pepper to taste.
4. In a large bowl, toss the kale with the dressing until it is evenly coated.
5. Serve immediately or store in the refrigerator for later.

This recipe is a perfect and healthy dinner option. The kale is packed with nutrients and the dressing made with almond butter, apple cider vinegar and agave nectar adds a delicious flavor to the kale.

Provide instructions for the given exercise.

output:
Leg Raises are a full-body exercise that can be done by lying on your back on a mat or carpeted floor. Place your hands under your lower back for support and engage your core muscles.

1. Begin by lying on your back with your hands under your lower back for support.
2. Lift your legs up towards the ceiling, keeping them straight and parallel to the ground.
3. Hold for a moment, then lower your legs back down to the starting position.
4. Repeat the movement for 10-15 times, then switch legs and repeat.
5. As you become more comfortable with the movement, you can increase the number of repetitions or the height of your leg lift.

Remember to keep your core muscles engaged throughout the exercise to protect your lower back.

instruction: Design a simple training challenge on Strava that everyone could attend.
output:
Training Challenge: "30 Days of Steps"

Objective: Encourage users to increase their daily step count for 30 days, while also promoting healthy habits and fostering a sense of community.

Duration: 30 days

1. Goal: Participants aim to accumulate a minimum of 10,000 steps per day for 30 consecutive days.
2. Challenges:
a. Daily check-ins: Participants must log their daily step count on Strava and share their progress in the challenge's group.
b. Weekly milestones: Reach 15,000 steps, 20,000 steps, and 25,000 steps within the first 14 days to unlock additional rewards and recognition.
c. Spotlight: A different participant will be featured each day, showcasing their progress and inspiring others to keep going.
3. Rewards:
a. Digital badges: Earn a badge upon completion, and a special badge for reaching the 30-day goal.
b. Personalized certificate: All participants who complete the challenge will receive a certificate of achievement.
c. Community recognition: High-performing participants will be highlighted in the challenge's feed and social media channels.
d. Exclusive virtual swag: Completers will receive a limited-edition digital item to display on their Strava profile.
4. Start and end dates: The challenge will begin on the first day of the month and end on the last day of the month.
5. Join the challenge: To participate, search for the "30 Days of Steps" challenge on Strava and join the group.

This challenge encourages users to adopt a healthier lifestyle while fostering a sense of community and friendly competition. By providing rewards and recognition, participants will feel motivated to keep pushing themselves and achieve their goals.

"With a little give in them"
